I have one critique of the black lives matter movement. It is in my view the only legitimate critic of the movement. If there was a “white lives matter” movement, or an “Asian lives matter” or “fathers matter”, or “ blah blah blah matters” movement, it would still be the same objection I would have. I object to the assumptions that are implied in crying black lives matter: that Blacks are under a unique threat.People in general act as if black lives don't matter.My only critique of the black lives matter movement is that it is based on a false premise. Are black lives under a unique threat? The numbers indicate that blacks are victims of homicide more frequently than people from other races.  This data seems to justify the necessity of the black lives matter movement. Afterall, if there are more blacks killed than people of any other race, it means there is a problem. By that logic, a “male lives matter movement” is justified. I doubt anyone would look at the data and believe there should be protests over the disparity in homicide victims between the sexes. Furthermore, most blacks who are homicide victims are killed by other blacks. Of the 2925 blacks murdered in 2018, 2600 (almost 90%) of them were committed by other blacks. The black lives matter movement not only avoids such discussions, but sees the mention of black on black crime as disingenuous, and a distraction from the main issue. Hence, despite the numbers indicating that the major threat to black lives comes from other blacks, the movement focuses on the 10% of cases when a black is killed by people of other races. The movement seems to be a black lives matter when taken by other races movement. Even if you think the major issue is inter racial killings. You'll expect, given the data that there would be a “white lives matter” or “Latino lives matter” movement. The number of whites killed by blacks (514) is more than double the number of blacks killed by whites (234). You can find the data for inter racial killings here. I do not believe the disparity in numbers is because whites are under a unique, racially motivated threat. However, the black lives matter movement is based on the assumption that that blacks are under a unique racially motivated threat. The data doesn't support that assumption. When you consider the rate of police killings of civilians, a disproportionate number of blacks are killed.   First, if the mere existence of a disparity justifies the need for a black lives matter movement, a “male lives matter” movement is warranted too. It should be obvious that there are more variables than just race that need to be considered.  I don't think anyone would jump to the conclusion that because the police kills far more men than women, the killings are motivated by gender, yet there are many that jump to those kind of conclusions with regards to race. There are studies that indicate that there is no racial bias involved in a cop’s decision to pull the trigger. At least four careful studies have done this—one by Harvard economist Roland Fryer, one by a group of public-health researchers, one by economist Sendhil Mullainathan, and one by David Johnson, et al. Not only is the central claim of the black lives matter movement —that racist cops target blacks —false, the claim is usually extrapolated to other parts of society. Many in the black lives movement would not object to the claim that: cops target blacks, this shows that America is racist. The claim about racist cops isn't true, and the conclusion that the country is racist is not supported. Do people act as if black lives don't matter? I think its obvious that society at large doesn't act as if black lives don't matter. People are generally more outraged by the brutal death of a black man than for the death of a white man. There is more media coverage when a black person is killed. Its more likely that you can name more black people who have been killed by cops than white people who have been killed by cops. Most news outlet spend more time covering stories involving a cop killing an unarmed black person than they spend for an unarmed white person. This proves that the black lives matter movement is based on a false narrative, that people act as if black lives don't matter. Coleman Hughes gives some stories that drive home the point. Each story in this paragraph involves a police officer killing an unarmed white person. (To demonstrate how commonly this happens, I have taken all of them from a single year, 2015, chosen at random). William Lemmon was killed after he allegedly failed to show his hands upon request; the shooting was ruled justified. No criminal charges were filed. Ralph Willis was shot dead when officers mistakenly thought that he was reaching for a gun. Six-year-old Jeremy Mardis was killed by a police officer while sitting in the passenger seat of a car; the officer’s intended target was Jeremy’s father, who was sitting in the driver’s seat with his hands raised out the window. Shortly after he killed her, bodycam footage revealed the officer’s despair: “I’m f------ going to prison,” he says. The officer was not disciplined. I am fascinated by the reaction to the Black Lives Matter movement, and after some discussions with very observant friends I’ve realised something quite important about what’s going on. BLM poses a challenge to the entire progressive narrative of our time. Firstly, BLM is an obviously valid movement. It began as a very simple public indication of racial persecution. There’s no valid criticism of that. Black people have suffered injustice, continue to do so, and that ought to be appreciated and corrected. However, there is a sting in the tail… Black Lives Matter necessarily invokes identity politics, and this is where the modern social narrative begins to crumble under the weight of the BLM’s claims on justice. Black people are defining themselves in contrast to other people and refusing to have that identity degraded. BLM says to white guys like me ‘you are not us, you cannot be us, and you do not speak for us’ - and they are right. But such claims are hardly acceptable in this day and age. Imagine if someone of exclusively Caucasian physical characteristics were to declare that they identified as black? Imagine what the reaction from the Black Community would be if someone decided they were going to live as a black person because that’s who they are and any opposition to that is trans-racio-phobic? What’s wrong with people of ‘other races’ becoming what they know themselves to be? How dare cis-racial communities be so exclusivist and ignorant such that they deny the fact that ‘race’ and ‘culture’ is entirely equivalent to ‘sex’ and ‘gender’? What is ‘race’? What is ‘blackness’? In what way do they differ from the chromosomal kaleidoscope and spectrum of human physical existence that we have already transcended and fluidly traverse in judgement-free power? Why should any person be saddled with their ‘birth race’, and refused recognition by those who just so happen to have the segregational social power to declare who is and who isn’t something because they were apportioned certain physical phenotypes without any intention being involved? Hence, ‘‘All lives matter”, because the assertion that ‘Black’ lives are somehow different in a way that is exclusively defined and defended from ideological incursion is antithetical to the progress of western social norms and serves as a stark reminder that identity is something that is not merely an individual matter but a corporate one. ‘‘All lives matter” (whilst superficially serving as a self-evident and egalitarian statement) is ironically acting as a sort of silencer of black pride and the pain that is associated with it. Blackface is becoming illegal in a world where Drag is celebrated. The resilience and resistance of a community to the efforts of outsiders to force them to conform to conditions defined by that out-group is undermining all sorts of efforts by all sorts of other movements to dissolve boundaries and remove distinctions. Black Lives Matter is drawing lines of contrast that modern cosmopolitans have long been uncomfortable with. In a moment of righteous anger they have rebelled against something even bigger than race relations, and no mechanisms of amelioration exist that do not threaten the interests of others. Black Lives Matter has dared to say who is who and what is what. Black Lives Matter, in the name of equality and cohesion, has violated the new sacred code of non-resistance. Black Lives Matter have refused to let others take what belongs to them - their identity - and redefine it in a way that renders all lives equally individual and thereby homogeneous. Black Lives Matter has, in pursuit of justice, put a dark stain on the rainbow tapestry of today’s progressive ideals. Oh, the irony. What shall we do, when ‘they’ are not ‘us’ and boundaries are being built rather than blurred?  Hence, blackness is what everything else determines it to be edit: in no way is this article intended to be ‘x-phobic’. It is making the point that the ‘-phobic’ terminology itself emerged from certain groups defining themselves exclusively. If anything, everyone is ‘‘xenophobic”, sheerly by virtue of the fact of conflict. People want people to have ‘‘common sense”, but we all want to decide what that is. As a friend of mine, one of the most tolerant and peacemaking people I know once said: “I oppose only those who oppose others”. Later I believe he saw the infinite irony of the statement.

So, although others have answered this question very well, I’m going to add another voice to the conversation anyway. Because there’s much more at play here than can been seen on the surface. BLM specifically is combative, exclusive, and reactionary. All these characteristics cause problems, but, more importantly, none are likely to influence any desirable change. The biggest problem with any movement that possesses these characteristics is that, at best, they shine more light on the symptoms of the actual problem than they do on the problem that caused the symptoms. And likewise, participants in the movement often spend a great deal of time and effort working to take action to address those symptoms rather than their cause. The problem is not that any one person or more were killed wrongly by a Police Officer. The problem is how Police Officers operate (not necessarily due to any fault of their own, as individuals). And ultimately that Police Officers exist at all. That’s not to suggest that they don’t provide some valid services, but that by giving them ‘too much’ power they have become something more than what a civilized society needs (a civilized society needn’t be policed); and that they therefore interfere with our societies ability to get on in a civilized manner. Further, the problem that BLM is attempting to address is rooted in prejudice; and prejudices can ultimately not be eradicated.
